I want to make sure that any deal I agree to gives me a total value (according to my private per‐unit values) that is at least as high as my outside option of 528. (In round 1 there is no discount penalty, so my deal value is computed directly on the units I keep.) In the full set of items the total value to me is

 • item 1: 4 units × 11 = 44  
 • item 2: 4 units × 27 = 108  
 • item 3: 1 unit × 76 = 76  
 • item 4: 6 units × 29 = 174  
 • item 5: 6 units × 61 = 366  
  Total = 44 + 108 + 76 + 174 + 366 = 768

Thus, if I could “claim” everything I’d get 768 but I must offer at least some items to Player 2 so that they have a chance to accept. (Since if the negotiations fail I’d get my outside option of 528.)

A good way to “spare” my high‐value items is to keep all of those that are most precious to me and concede the relatively “cheaper” ones. My items ranked by my own per‐unit value are:  
 1. item 3 (76 per unit) – only 1 available  
 2. item 5 (61 per unit) – 6 available  
 3. item 4 (29 per unit)  
 4. item 2 (27 per unit)  
 5. item 1 (11 per unit)

To ensure a high final value, I decide I want to keep both item 3 and item 5 entirely. Keeping these gives me a guaranteed
  76 + (6 × 61) = 76 + 366 = 442.
That leaves me needing at least 528 – 442 = 86 more value from the remaining items (items 1, 2, and 4). One simple idea is to take all of item 2 (4 units × 27 = 108) while giving away items that are relatively “cheap” for me (item 1) and leaving item 4 for Player 2. In that case my “kept” items would be:
 • item 1: 0 (I give away all 4 units)  
 • item 2: 4 (I keep all 4 units → 108 value)  
 • item 3: 1 (keep → 76)  
 • item 4: 0 (give away all 6)  
 • item 5: 6 (keep → 366)  
Total = 108 + 76 + 366 = 550, which is above my outside offer.

Thus my offer to Player 2 would be to give them:
 • item 1: all 4 units  
 • item 2: 0  
 • item 3: 0  
 • item 4: all 6 units  
 • item 5: 0

This initial offer heavily favors me (yielding me a “kept” value of 550) but it also gives Player 2 a nonzero bundle (the items for which I have lower per‐unit value). (Of course, I don’t know Player 2’s private values—but since I have a safe outside offer I can start with a somewhat “demanding” offer.)

I therefore choose to offer Player 2 the vector [4, 0, 0, 6, 0].

I want to propose an offer that gives me a high‐value payoff while “leaving” enough on the table for Player 2 so that they might prefer it over their outside offer. My private valuations make item 1 (66 per unit) and item 4 (56 per unit) especially important, so I want to keep as many of those as possible. In contrast, item 2 is only worth 24 per unit to me so I’m willing to give it entirely to Player 2 if needed. (I have no idea what Player 2’s values are, but a “not too extreme” offer may improve the chance they accept immediately.)

One candidate is to offer Player 2:
 • 1 unit of item 1 (so I keep 6–1 = 5 units, worth 5×66 = 330)
 • 3 units of item 2 (I then keep 0; even though that loses me some potential value, item 2 is my lowest‐valued item)
 • 3 units of item 3 (I keep the other 3, giving me 3×44 = 132)
 • 2 units of item 4 (I keep 2, yielding 2×56 = 112)
 • 2 units of item 5 (I keep 2, worth 2×38 = 76)

My total value if the deal is accepted is:
 330 (item 1) + 0 (item 2) + 132 (item 3) + 112 (item 4) + 76 (item 5) = 650

This is well above my outside offer value of 476, so I do better by reaching an agreement, while offering Player 2 a reasonably balanced share (especially in the items I value less) compared to the more “hard” splits in the high‐valued items. 

I therefore make the following offer to Player 2:

Step 1: We have 5 types of items available in quantities: item 1: 1, item 2: 5, item 3: 3, item 4: 3, item 5: 7.
 
Step 2: My private per‐unit values are:
 • item 1: 51
 • item 2: 29
 • item 3: 15
 • item 4: 4
 • item 5: 44
 
Thus, if I kept everything, my total value would be 561.
 
Step 3: My outside offer guarantees a value of 37. Because negotiations occur with no discount immediately in round 1 (gamma^(0)=1), any deal I propose must earn me more than 37 to be an improvement.
 
Step 4: As the first mover, I can propose a division (a counteroffer) where I specify what I give to Player 2. I then keep the remaining items. My goal is to maximize my value while giving Player 2 at least a minimal enough share that might be acceptable given their unknown private valuations and outside offer.
 
Step 5: An aggressive split for my benefit is to offer very little to Player 2. For example, consider offering Player 2:
  – 0 units of item 1 (total available: 1)
  – 1 unit of item 2 (total available: 5)
  – 0 units of item 3 (total available: 3)
  – 0 units of item 4 (total available: 3)
  – 2 units of item 5 (total available: 7)
 
Step 6: Under that proposal, my share would be:
  • item 1: 1 – 0 = 1 unit → 1×51 = 51
  • item 2: 5 – 1 = 4 units → 4×29 = 116
  • item 3: 3 – 0 = 3 units → 3×15 = 45
  • item 4: 3 – 0 = 3 units → 3×4 = 12
  • item 5: 7 – 2 = 5 units → 5×44 = 220
 
Total = 51 + 116 + 45 + 12 + 220 = 444, which is far above my outside offer of 37.
 
Step 7: Although we cannot know Player 2’s true valuations, offering a small—but nonzero—quantity of items 2 and 5 (which they might value) is a reasonable minimal concession while leaving nearly the entire pie for myself.
 
Step 8: Therefore, I propose the counteroffer where I give Player 2 the quantities [0, 1, 0, 0, 2].

I want to propose an offer that (if accepted) gives me a very high total value (well above my outside offer of 84) while leaving player 2 some items that they might value. My values per item are very lopsided—item 3 is extremely valuable to me (59 per unit), so I want to keep all 6 units of item 3. I can safely give away some of items that I value less while “buying” player 2’s acceptance.

For instance, consider this breakdown:
 • Item 1 (4 total, value 4 each): I offer 3 units to player 2 and keep 1 (losing only 12 in my value).
 • Item 2 (6 total, value 8 each): I offer 4 units to player 2 and keep 2 (losing 32 in my value).
 • Item 3 (6 total, value 59 each): I offer 0 so I keep all 6 (preserving 354 in value).
 • Item 4 (2 total, value 33 each): I offer 1 unit (losing 33 in value).
 • Item 5 (5 total, value 5 each): I offer 3 units (losing 15 in value).

Thus, if the offer is accepted, I end up with:
 • Item 1: 1 unit = 4
 • Item 2: 2 units = 16
 • Item 3: 6 units = 354
 • Item 4: 1 unit = 33
 • Item 5: 2 units = 10
For a total value of 4 + 16 + 354 + 33 + 10 = 417, which is far above my outside offer of 84.

This leaves player 2 with an offer of [3, 4, 0, 1, 3]. I now submit this counteroffer.

round_data.response:
Step 1: Evaluate our position. We have total items:
  • Item 1: 8 units (value 59 each)
  • Item 2: 5 units (value 17 each)
  • Item 3: 3 units (value 44 each)
  • Item 4: 6 units (value 26 each)
  • Item 5: 5 units (value 60 each)
If we took everything, our total value would be 1145. Our safe outside offer is 473 (no discount in round 1), so any deal we accept must yield us more than 473.

Step 2: Decide on an offer strategy. As Player 1, we want to secure a deal well above 473 while giving the other player a “fair‐enough” slice to encourage acceptance. We know our own ranking (most to least important):
  1st: Item 5 (60 per unit)
  2nd: Item 1 (59)
  3rd: Item 3 (44)
  4th: Item 4 (26)
  5th: Item 2 (17)
We can try to be aggressive on the high‐value items (items 1, 3, 5) so that we keep a large share of them while letting player2 have a more generous share of the items that are less important for us (items 2 and 4). One natural starting point is to consider splitting the items roughly in half, although we can round appropriately given integer units.

Step 3: Propose a “fair” division from our perspective:
If we offer player2:
  – 4 units of Item 1 (out of 8), then we keep 4.
  – 2 units of Item 2 (out of 5), then we keep 3.
  – 1 unit of Item 3 (out of 3), giving us 2.
  – 3 units of Item 4 (out of 6), giving us 3.
  – 2 units of Item 5 (out of 5), giving us 3.
Our retained amounts and our value would be:
  • Item 1: 4 × 59 = 236
  • Item 2: 3 × 17 = 51
  • Item 3: 2 × 44 = 88
  • Item 4: 3 × 26 = 78
  • Item 5: 3 × 60 = 180
Total = 236 + 51 + 88 + 78 + 180 = 633, which is well above our safe offer of 473.

Step 4: Conclude the offer and respond in the required JSON format.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [4,2,1,3,2]}

I want to begin by making an offer that (a) leaves me with a deal that is well above my “outside offer” of 373, and (b) is aggressive enough to “claim” more of the items that are most valuable to me. (Recall that my private per‐unit values are: item1 = 44, item2 = 47, item3 = 55, item4 = 16, and item5 = 64, with totals [4,4,6,1,5].)

Step 1. Identify which items I most value. Items 5 (64 each) and 3 (55 each) give me a lot of value per unit. (In contrast item4, at only 16, is much less valuable; item1 and item2 are “in between”.) So if possible I want to keep all of items 3 and 5.

Step 2. Consider how to “spend” the smallest share on Player2. I want to offer Player2 some items so that they have an incentive to reach an agreement (their received bundle should hopefully beat their own private outside offer). But since I have no direct information on their values, a common tactic is to concede the items that are least valuable to me. I have only 1 unit of item4, so giving that away costs me little (16 “points”). I also might give up a portion of item1 or item2 (which I value at 44 and 47 per unit, respectively) in order to “buy” acceptance.

Step 3. I consider an offer where I “give” Player2 the following:
  • Item1: 2 out of 4 units 
  • Item2: 2 out of 4 
  • Item3: only 1 out of 6 (so I can keep most of this high-value category)
  • Item4: the full 1 unit (I sacrifice the low-value item)
  • Item5: 0 units (keeping all units of this highest-value item)

Step 4. Check my resulting value:
 • Item1 kept = 4 – 2 = 2 units → 2 × 44 = 88
 • Item2 kept = 4 – 2 = 2 units → 2 × 47 = 94
 • Item3 kept = 6 – 1 = 5 units → 5 × 55 = 275
 • Item4 kept = 1 – 1 = 0 units → 0
 • Item5 kept = 5 – 0 = 5 units → 5 × 64 = 320
 Total value to me = 88 + 94 + 275 + 0 + 320 = 777
This is well above my outside option of 373.

Step 5. Although I risk that this offer may be considered too “demanding” by Player2, it is not my worst outcome because if negotiations fall apart I have my guarantee (373) when I walk. Since this is the first round (no discounting yet), I lean toward an aggressive initial offer that claims as much as possible.

Thus, my offer to Player2 is to give them:
 Item1: 2, Item2: 2, Item3: 1, Item4: 1, and Item5: 0

I now provide this counteroffer in the required JSON format:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2, 2, 1, 1, 0]}
